subject: Self Care
title: The Cost of Multitasking
description: A quick win: understand The Cost of Multitasking.

hook.text: You think you're multitasking. Your brain is actually switching between tasks rapidly, losing efficiency each time.

buildup.text: Task switching has a cognitive cost: each switch requires the brain to reload context. This costs time and accuracy.

discovery.text: Stanford research showed that heavy multitaskers are worse at filtering, memory, and switching than single-taskers.

twist.text: People who multitask the most are the worst at it. The habit degrades the very skills it requires. It's a downward spiral.

climax.text: Do one thing at a time. Close other tabs. Silence the phone. Single-tasking produces better work in less time.

punchline.text: Multitasking is a myth. Single-focus wins every time.

quiz.question: What did Stanford research reveal about heavy multitaskers?
options: They are worse at filtering, memory, and task-switching
